awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Fishing through antiquity in central Alaska: exploring the abundance and use of salmon through stable isotope, zooarchaeological, and ancient DNA analyses
awd_abstract_narration:
The primary goals of the proposed research are to reconstruct changes in salmon abundance and explore human use of salmon in central Alaska from the earliest occupations during the last Ice Age (~13,000 years ago) through the late prehistoric period. Today, salmon make up the largest proportion of wild foods harvested by rural Alaskans, but the availability of this important subsistence resource is declining in many upriver areas. Research on prehistoric salmon abundance and use can provide data critical to understanding natural variation in salmon availability and how northern riverine peoples have responded to fluctuations in this important resource in the past.  By providing a long-term perspective for sustainability and food security planning, project data will benefit a variety of salmon stakeholders within Alaska and beyond. The project has a strong educational component, including the development and delivery of a project-based course for the Rural Alaska Honors Institute (a college preparatory program for rural and Alaska Native college-bound students), thus enhancing opportunities for underrepresented groups.

This project will address three questions:  (1) How has salmon abundance varied over time in central Alaska? (2) When did prehistoric foragers begin to use salmon, and when did they begin to intensively exploit this resource? (3) How did foragers respond to changes in salmon availability? To address these questions, a multidisciplinary team will use independent approaches: (a) stable isotope analysis of human and faunal remains will reveal the contribution of salmon to the diets of prehistoric salmon consumers (e.g., humans, dogs, bears); (b) zooarchaeological and ancient DNA analyses of fish remains from existing faunal assemblages will allow reconstruction of past fish procurement and processing strategies; and (c) stable isotope analysis of interior lake sediment cores will track natural fluctuations in salmon abundance.  These data will be integrated with models of forager economy and mobility to explore cultural responses to salmon abundance through multiple prehistoric periods. This research will provide the necessary faunal isotope data to accurately reconstruct overall paleodiets of newly discovered multiple human individuals at the interior sites of Upward Sun River (~11,500 yrs old) and Tochak (~1000 yrs old), where faunal and initial isotopic data suggest significant salmon use.  This project provides unprecedented time depth on natural variation in salmon abundance in the North Pacific and in understanding how northern peoples have responded to changes in this critical resource in the past. The study will produce much-needed direct data bearing on prehistoric subsistence strategies in the Alaskan interior throughout the period of human occupation.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this project was to explore human use of salmon and other fish in central Alaska from the earliest occupations until historic times. To address this goal, we used a variety of approaches, including stable isotope analyses of human and faunal remains to reveal the contribution of salmon to diets, and identification of fish remains from archaeological sites to understand trends in salmon and other fish use.

For this project, we sampled the skeletal remains of five prehistoric humans (with the approval of the descendant Alaska Native communities), including two infants from the Upward Sun River site (~11,500 years ago) in the Tanana Valley and three individuals from the Tochak site (~500 to 1000 years ago) on the upper Kuskokwim River. We analyzed bone collagen carbon and nitrogen stable isotope values to reveal the contributions of different sources of protein to diet. The bone collagen isotopic composition of the USR infants reflects the diets of their mothers, and we showed that while terrestrial resources such as bison and wapiti (elk) dominated the maternal diets, salmon was also important. These conclusions were supported by additional stable isotope analyses of individual amino acids, bone bioapatite, and tooth enamel bioapatite. Our findings thus contradict the popular notion that early Native Americans were strictly big-game hunters. Isotopic analysis of the Tochak individuals revealed that diets were dominated by both freshwater fish and anadromous salmon. This was an unexpected finding, since historically Upper Kuskokwim populations focused on terrestrial game.

We analyzed over 4000 fish bones from central Alaska, identifying them to the most precise taxonomic level possible using standard zooarchaeological morphological techniques. A subset of 34 fish were identified using ancient DNA sequencing techniques. Our results show that by 13,000-12,000 years ago (at the tail end of the last Ice Age) ancient Alaskans in the Tanana Valley were using freshwater fish, and by at least 11,500 years ago people in the region were using salmon, which DNA analyses show were chum salmon. Fish remains from other areas in central Alaska date to later in time and include chum, sockeye, and king salmon, as well as burbot, whitefish, pike, and long nose sucker.

Overall, our results show the great time depth of fishing for both freshwater fish and salmon to populations in central Alaska. This long-term perspective on fish use will benefit a range of stakeholders, including fish-dependent Alaska Native and other Native American communities, fisheries managers and biologists, and resource policymakers.

Over the course of this project, 20 rural and Alaska Native college-bound students in the Rural Alaska Honors Institute participated in authentic project research through the Ancient Peoples and Animals of Alaska class. This college-level course was taught by project staff through the University of Alaska Fairbanks and culminated in research poster presentations by the students.


Last Modified: 05/19/2020
Modified by: Carrin M Halffman
